stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Newly identified Zbot trojan sample analysis
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 19 July 2013, a piece of malware was observed. Subsequently, the malware with its associated files were submitted for analysis. These files are variants of the Zbot trojan. The trojan drops five files in the %TEMP% and %APPDATA% directories. The files attempt to connect to four Command and Control servers (C2).
This document incorporates information originally released as US-CERT MIFR-299017.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
This malware is a PWS-ZBOT trojan and runs on a Win32 platform. This type of trojan steals sensitive information from the victim machine and sends the information to a remote host. It checks for installed applications and then attempts to grab passwords, users, and server information on the victim machine. Embedded in the code is a password list used by the malware to brute force the accounts.
In addition to modifying the registry and the file system, the malware has networking functionality and was observed making attempts to communicate with several domains via ports 80. There were also strings embedded in the file that suggest that it may attempt to connect to servers on ports 443 and 8080. A Facebook website was embedded in the code.
This malware is packed with a custom packer, thus making static analysis more difficult. Dumping the executable and analyzing the strings yielded relevant information that includes the password list, dependencies and the batch script used for deleting files. These strings are located in the .dbg image section of the executable. The process, "cmd.exe", is created to execute the batch file used to delete the loader file after execution.

 del 	 %0 shell32.dll ;3+#>6.& '2, /+0&7!4-)1# CreateFileA ReadFile CloseHandle WriteFile lstrlenA GlobalLock GlobalUnlock LocalFree LocalAlloc GetTickCount lstrcpyA lstrcatA GetFileAttributesA ExpandEnvironmentStringsA GetFileSize CreateFileMappingA MapViewOfFile UnmapViewOfFile LoadLibraryA GetProcAddress GetTempPathA CreateDirectoryA DeleteFileA GetCurrentProcess WideCharToMultiByte GetLastError lstrcmpA CreateToolhelp32Snapshot Process32First OpenProcess Process32Next FindFirstFileA lstrcmpiA FindNextFileA FindClose GetModuleHandleA GetVersionExA GetLocaleInfoA GetSystemInfo GetWindowsDirectoryA GetPrivateProfileStringA SetCurrentDirectoryA GetPrivateProfileSectionNamesA GetPrivateProfileIntA GetCurrentDirectoryA lstrlenW MultiByteToWideChar Sleep GetModuleFileNameA LCMapStringA ExitProcess SetUnhandledExceptionFilter kernel32.dll CreateStreamOnHGlobal GetHGlobalFromStream CoCreateGuid CoTaskMemFree CoCreateInstance OleInitialize ole32.dll wsprintfA user32.dll RegOpenKeyExA RegQueryValueExA RegCloseKey RegOpenKeyA RegEnumKeyExA RegCreateKeyA RegSetValueExA IsTextUnicode RegOpenCurrentUser RegEnumValueA GetUserNameA advapi32.dll ShellExecuteA shell32.dll InternetCrackUrlA InternetCreateUrlA wininet.dll StrStrIA StrRChrIA StrToIntA StrStrA StrCmpNIA StrStrIW shlwapi.dll ObtainUserAgentString urlmon.dll inet_addr gethostbyname socket connect closesocket send select recv setsockopt WSAStartup wsock32.dll LoadUserProfileA UnloadUserProfile userenv.dll

This file has a different hash value than file MD5: 06c3a27772c2552a28c32f82583b7645. However, it has the same physical characteristics, behavior and dependencies as the file with hash MD5: 06c3a27772c2552a28c32f82583b7645.

The user's privilege level on the system determines the process into which the malicious code will be injected. If the user has admin level privileges, then the malware's code will be injected into "winlogon.exe". If the user has user level privileges, its code will be injected into "explorer.exe". The malware, "ttcopy.scr", injected its code into "explorer.exe".
Upon execution, the malware performed registry and file manipulation functions to add persistence, create firewall rules to bypass authentication, clear browser cookies and modify Internet Explorer (IE) to lower the security of its IE zone settings.
The malware made an attempt to communicate with a remote server, hcserver.com.br, to download a config file, "/coslar/cfg.bin". The attempted communication is via port 80.
Several files were added and modified by the malware. The following were temporarily written to disk and then removed: %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\tmp[random numbers_letters].bat %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\MPS6.tmp %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Application Data\Identities\{277C436D-2518-4089-9373-48CD39D2B252}\Microsoft\Outlook Express\Inbox.dbx %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Application Data\Identities\{277C436D-2518-4089-9373-48CD39D2B252}\Microsoft\Outlook Express\Sent Items.dbx
The following have been added: %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\file.exe %USERPROFILE%\Application Data\[RANDOM_FOLDER]\[RANDOM_FILENAME].exe %USERPROFILE%\Application Data\[RANDOM_FOLDER]\[RANDOM_FILENAME].[RANDOM_EXTENSION]
An executable file and a data file above with random names are created inside the %APPDATA% directory. The subfolder names starts with an uppercase letter.
A process, "cmd.exe", is created to execute the batch file, "tmp.[random numbers_letters].bat". This batch file is created in the user's %TEMP% directory. The purpose of the batch file is to delete the original loader file after execution and then delete itself.
The contents of "tmp.[random numbers_letters].bat" is displayed below: @echo off :d del "%USERPROFILE%\Desktop\infected\ttcopy.scr" if exist "%USERPROFILE%\Desktop\infected\ttcopy.scr" goto d del /F "%USERPROFILE%\LOCALS~1\Temp\tmp[RANDOM_NUMBERS&LETTERS].bat"
-----Section Header Hashes----- 8f3dd55ca662e55f533fb4ee24db75e1 (header) 1024 abc723b1960e7cc5224e16bfe4b8b9a2 .text 108544 5b25b475c1d3897b350d98f80db5ec0a .rdata 23040 16cb4af12a851e5dabef827f5219505e .data 6656 7d37623f772315fcaf1924184ce31e43 .rsrc 69120 44e6e86a4e71007505d69d83f50e18c4 .reloc 9216

This file is dropped by the file with hash MD5: 2f63246799262b3b6dd83a7ac25f39a2. The malware, "ttcopy.scr", dropped two executable files with the same hash in two directories, %TEMP% and %APPDATA%. %USERPROFILE%\Local Settings\Temp\file.exe %USERPROFILE%\Application Data\[RANDOM_FOLDER]\[RANDOM_FILENAME].exe
These executable files are encrypted and analysis of the encrypted files was not performed.
Additional file names: udwo.exe
-----Section Header Hashes----- 8f3dd55ca662e55f533fb4ee24db75e1 (header) 1024 abc723b1960e7cc5224e16bfe4b8b9a2 .text 108544 5b25b475c1d3897b350d98f80db5ec0a .rdata 23040 16cb4af12a851e5dabef827f5219505e .data 6656 7d37623f772315fcaf1924184ce31e43 .rsrc 69120 44e6e86a4e71007505d69d83f50e18c4 .reloc 9216

The data file, "yzky.tmp", is dropped by the malware (MD5: 2f63246799262b3b6dd83a7ac25f39a2) in the %APPDATA% directory. %USERPROFILE%\Application Data\[RANDOM_FOLDER]\[RANDOM_FILENAME].[RANDOM_EXTENSION] This file is obfuscated.
